Award.AwardTitle: Developing Pedagogies of Engagement in Foundation Chemistry Courses: Enhancing Minority Retention in STEM Majors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemistry Department is encouraging more engagement of students with course content by incorporating, in a systematic and multi-course fashion, the use of novel case studies in General Chemistry discussion sections and in Organic Chemistry Laboratory sections. The project is implementing problem-based case studies that focus on the interdisciplinary aspect of chemistry in these foundational courses taken by large numbers of first- and second-year students. This allows the students to make connections between traditional content and topics of civic relevance that are well-matched to current students interests. The project is focusing on connections to environmental science, biomedical science, and engineering and is establishing how this approach leads to increased retention of students in their pursuit of STEM degrees.

The introduction of case study discussions is changing the learning environment for the targeted chemistry courses; students are engaged in a more active and collaborative learning experience from that which existed prior to the start of this project. In addition, the inclusion of case studies is furthering students' development of higher order critical thinking skills. The project is developing Teaching Assistant expertise to lead open-ended case study discussions and is assessing the impact of this educational experience on TA performance and expected future use.

The project is demonstrating how existing courses can be tweaked such that even large enrollment foundational chemistry courses can engage all students in an active and collaborative environment known to develop desired student skills. Simultaneously, the project, by connecting students to real world issues of current civic relevance, is increasing the success rate of students by directly confronting a commonly perceived deficiency in current course offerings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcomes and anticipated impact are summarized as follows:

1) A collection of problem-based case studies for both general chemistry and organic chemistry was designed and successfully implemented in these two large enrollment gateway courses;

2) Assessment results indicate the implementation of these case study activities in general chemistry do not negatively impact student performance compared to more traditional lecture approaches, and in some cases student performance in general chemistry was positively impacted. When the problem-based case studies were implemented using a blended learning/flipped learning approach, in which the case studies were completed in the lecture meetings as opposed to  weekly recitation sections, multiple regression analysis found student performance in the first quarter general course improved compared to control groups in which no case studies were implemented. Specifically, it was found that students in the case study treatment group performed approximatley 18% better in their final course grade compared to the control group. Student performance was also positively impacted in the third quarter general chemistry course, as multiple regression analysis found students who participated in the case study intervention performed approximatley 27% better than control students who were enrolled in more traditional lecture courses. Assessment results also suggest overall retention rates were postively impacted in the general chemistry course sequence, as students who participated in the case study intervention had D/F/W rates of 4.5% for the second quarter course and 1.9% for the third quarter course. These are compared to 10.4% and 5.7% D/F/W rates for control groups in the second and third quarter courses, respectively. Statistical ansalysis found there was a positive correlation between participating in the case study courses and improved student retention;

3) Given the fact the organic chemistry case studies had to be implemented in the organic laboratory course, which is graded separtately from the organic chemistry lecture course, it was not possible to determine correlation between participating in the case study activities and student success in organic chemistry. However, Student Assessment of Learning Gains (SALG) surveys were used to measure student interest and engagement in the course after participating in the case study activities. Results from these surveys are mixed, as student gains in interest in organic chemistry and their confidence in being able to relate organic chemistry to real world problems were not always positive. However, it is noted student gains in the third quarter organic chemistry lab course were postive in both their ability to connect course content to real world problems and understanding how small molecule pro-drug strategies are carried out;

4) The primary impact of this project will be the fact the development and implementation of the problem-based case studies described herein has added significantly to the available case study resources for general chemistry and organic chemistry. Five new cases for general chemistry and two new cases for organic chemistry are now available online at the NCCSTS case study collection. These cases are advertised by the NCCSTS to a faculty list-serve that numbers in the thousands, and these materials are freely available to instructors across the country. As more faculty are exposed to these new case study materials, there should be a positive impact on the increased use of active learning pedagogies in these gateway introductory chemistry courses;
